body: New York City transportation officials shut down a subway line across the Manhattan Bridge yesterday after state inspectors found deep corrosion, sheared bolts and missing steel plates in the bridge's beams that support the tracks. In one spot, a plate that was supposed to hold a six-inch-wide beam in place was missing, said David Steinberger, the
title: Hazards Halt Manhattan Bridge Subway Line

body: A 31-year-old immigrant from Ethiopia with a load of Christmas packages was shot and killed in the driveway of his house in Far Rockaway, Queens, on Christmas Eve, the police said yesterday. The man, Berhane Waldermarian, was one of at least 10 New Yorkers killed in separate incidents on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day. Among them were a Bronx baby
title: Ethiopian Immigrant Carrying Christmas Gifts Is Slain in Queens

body: A customer in a Coney Island furniture store shot one man to death and critically injured another yesterday as the two were robbing patrons and the store owners, the police said. The two armed men entered the store, the Furniture Showcase by Crawford at 2005 Coney Island Avenue, in Brooklyn, at 5:35 P.M. and threatened customers, said Officer Fred
title: Robber in a Furniture Store Shot to Death by a Customer

body: New York City transit officials said yesterday that service cuts proposed on Wednesday are part of a new budget-driven strategy of tailoring service more closely to the fluctuations in ridership. For decades, the Transit Authority has provided subway and bus service to all New Yorkers, at all hours of the day and night, including weekends, without
title: Transit Cuts Called First Of Many Painful Moves

body: The New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that to save money it planned to shorten several subway lines after midnight and eliminate dozens of express and local bus routes outright. title: Transit Agency Seeks to Cut Back On Buses and Some Subway Runs

title: Opposition to Condom Plan By Some Principals Is Seen

body: Anthony F. Russo, dean of students at Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn, died on Thursday at Coney Island Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I. title: Anthony F. Russo, Dean, 55

body: The Homecrest Presbyterian Church, at 15th Street and Avenue T in Brooklyn, stands only a block from the D train, but the white wooden structure carries its 90 years with an almost rural dignity. Set back from the street behind a lush yard, it is a relic of a time when this part of the borough was passing from farmland to suburban neighborhood.
title: Beliefs
